did.unittitle: Frank Baker Collection of Methodist circuit plans 1777-1984 and undated
did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Library's online catalog.
did.abstract: Scholar, editor, collector, and Duke University faculty member specializing in the history of English and American Methodist history, and of the life and career of minister John Wesley. The Frank Baker Collection of Methodist Circuit Plans, 1777-1984 and undated, consists predominantly of circuit plans from the Methodist Church (Great Britain) and the earlier churches that merged to form it in 1907 and 1932: the Wesleyan Methodist Church, the Primitive Methodist Church, the United Methodist Free Churches, and the United Methodist Church (Great Britain). These plans document the history, growth, and organization of the itinerancy, established by John Wesley in the early years of the church when Methodism began to spread into the rural areas of England. The circuit plans feature detailed schedules of where the itinerant preachers, known as circuit riders, were to appear and preach each week.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Researchers must register and agree to copyright and privacy laws before using this collection.
All or portions of this collection may be housed off-site in Duke University's Library Service Center. The library may require up to 48 hours to retrieve these materials for research use.
Please contact Research Services staff before visiting the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library to use this collection.

userestrict.head: Copyright Notice
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Frank Baker Collection of Methodist Circuit Plans, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Frank Baker Collection of Methodist Circuit Plans were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a gift in 1976, 1996.

processinfo.p: Processed by Marsha Kononenko, and Michael Shumate, February 2012

Accession(s) described in this finding aid: The 1976 gift and parts of accession 96-052 were merged into one collection, described in this finding aid.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The Frank Baker Collection of Methodist Circuit Plans, 1777-1984 and undated, consists predominantly of circuit plans from the Methodist Church (Great Britain) and the earlier churches that merged to form it in 1907 and 1932: the Wesleyan Methodist Church, the Primitive Methodist Church, the United Methodist Free Churches, and the United Methodist Church (Great Britain). These plans document the history, growth, and organization of the itinerancy, established by John Wesley in the early years of the church when Methodism began to spread into the rural areas of England. The circuit plans feature detailed schedules of where the itinerant preachers, known as circuit riders, were to appear and preach each week.

Items in the 19th Century and Overseas Circuits Series were donated in the 1970s and were organized at the item level and encapsulated in the early 1980s. Items were numbered in the order in which they were encapsulated, which bears no relationship to alphabetical order or circuit organization. They are currently boxed in numerical order in three boxes with the following number ranges: Box 1: items 1-240; Box 2, items 241-390; Box 3: items 391-527. The 20th Century Series, comprising circa 800-1000 items, was donated in the late 1980s and is organized to the folder level.

processinfo.p: [Processing note: Oversize items in this series have been transferred to Box 4 and are listed in a separate alphabetical sequence at the end of the series.]

scopecontent.p: Article by Frank Baker, The Circuit Plan, published in Library Notes, no. 49, 1979, Duke University Library.

scopecontent.p: Donated at a later date. Approximately 1500 circuit plans, mainly covering the years from 1944-1959, but with scattered plans from the 1890s and 1900s. Minimally processed; plans are grouped alphabetically by circuit name (or city, if circuit unclear), but are not in order within each letter.
